title: Genetic and demographic analysis of invasive Peromyscus leucopus in the northern Great Lakes region
abstract: Many organisms worldwide are responding to rapid climate change by shifting their geographic ranges. The white-footed mouse, Peromyscus leucopus, has expanded its range northward in Michigan and Wisconsin since 1980 and is now common in localities where it was previously unknown. To investigate the origin and history of the newly established populations, complete D-loop sequences were analyzed from 595 white-footed mice collected throughout the northern Great Lakes region. Mice from Wisconsin and the western Upper Peninsula (UP) of Michigan make up a well-differentiated lineage, while the eastern UP and the Lower Peninsula (LP) of Michigan form a second lineage. The two lineages diverged about 34,000 BP, well before they migrated to the Great Lakes region. The close genetic relationship between mice in the LP and those in the eastern UP is probably due primarily to accidental transport by humans and may have implications for the spread of Lyme disease in the Upper Midwest.

abstract.text: Many organisms worldwide are responding to rapid climate change by shifting their geographic ranges. The white-footed mouse, Peromyscus leucopus, has expanded its range northward in Michigan and Wisconsin since 1980 and is now common in localities where it was previously unknown. To investigate the origin and history of the newly established populations, complete D-loop sequences were analyzed from 595 white-footed mice collected throughout the northern Great Lakes region. Mice from Wisconsin and the western Upper Peninsula (UP) of Michigan make up a well-differentiated lineage, while the eastern UP and the Lower Peninsula (LP) of Michigan form a second lineage. The two lineages diverged about 34,000 BP, well before they migrated to the Great Lakes region. The close genetic relationship between mice in the LP and those in the eastern UP is probably due primarily to accidental transport by humans and may have implications for the spread of Lyme disease in the Upper Midwest.

body_text.text: The ranges of many terrestrial species in North America are undergoing rapid shifts due to climate change (Parmesan 2006; Moritz et al. 2008; Myers et al. 2009) and understanding the causes and consequences of these shifts is critical to developing effective conservation strategies (Buckley and Roughgarden 2004) . Some species can track suitable environmental conditions by moving to higher elevations (Moritz et al. 2008; Yang et al. 2011) or latitudes (Parmesan et al. 1999) , while the movement of other species may be constrained by geographic barriers (e.g., Coulon et al. 2006) . To understand how species will shift their ranges in the future, we should consider how they respond to such constraints, which may be illuminated not only by the course of recent migrations but also by looking back to the establishment of those species within their historical ranges.

The phylogeography of mammals in the Great Lakes region is of particular interest with respect to understanding range changes, in part because the lakes serve as substantial water barriers that can severely limit the redistribution of terrestrial species (Rowe et al. 2006; Taylor and Hoffman 2010) . Also, the region is relatively young, having been ice-free for only about 10,000 to 12,000 years (Pielou 1991; Holman 2001) , which is recent enough that some species still show genetic signatures of their postglacial migrations (Rowe et al. 2004 (Rowe et al. , 2006 Taylor and Hoffman 2010) . The region also encompasses a historical dividing line between two substantially different mammalian faunal assemblages (Baker 1983; Kurta 2017 ) associated with two different forest types, eastern deciduous forest across the southern part of the lakes and mixed deciduous-boreal forest to the north.

A species that has been rapidly shifting its range across this complex landscape is the white-footed mouse, Peromyscus leucopus noveboracensis, which has expanded northward over the last 40 years from the southern Great Lakes deciduous forests (Myers et al. 2009; Roy-Dufresne et al. 2013) , establishing new populations in the Upper Peninsula (UP) of Michigan (Myers et al. 2009; Baumgartner 2017 ) and in northernmost Wisconsin and Minnesota (Long 1996; Jannett et al. 2007) , as well as in southern Quebec (Roy-Dufresne et al. 2013) . This northward shift is most likely due to climatic change (Long 1996; Wolff 1996; Myers et al. 2005; Fiset et al. 2015) , in particular a trend toward shorter winters and the earlier onset of spring weather in the region (Magnuson et al. 2000; Myers et al. 2005) . Today, the white-footed mouse is very common in the mixed deciduous-boreal forests of northern Michigan and Wisconsin, where it typically coexists with the previously dominant mouse species, the woodland deer mouse, Peromyscus maniculatus gracilis (Myers et al. 2009; Baumgartner 2017) .

Peromyscus mice are the most common mammal species throughout much of the Great Lakes region, serving as important seed and insect predators and as prey for a variety of carnivores (e.g., Ostfeld et al. 1996) . Although the niches of P. leucopus and P. maniculatus overlap extensively, there are differences between the species that may prove to be important (Wolff 1996) . Of particular concern is that P. leucopus is a major natural reservoir for Borrelia burgdorferi, the bacterium that causes Lyme disease (Ostfeld et al. 2006; Cook and Barbour 2015) , while P. m. gracilis is considered to be a less-competent host (Fiset et al. 2015) . Peromyscus leucopus is also a common host for the major vector of Lyme disease in North America, the black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis (CDC 2017). The range expansion of P. leucopus is thus likely to increase the prevalence of Lyme disease in the region, especially if new populations are founded by mice from areas with high current rates of B. burgdorferi infection (Fiset et al. 2015) .

To date, the postglacial expansion of P. leucopus in this region is not well understood, despite its being one of the most studied rodent species in North America. The genetics of the recently established populations of P. leucopus in the UP of Michigan have been examined using microsatellites (Baumgartner and Hoffman 2019) , which revealed little genetic structure and high rates of gene flow, but these results do not shed light on the situation before 1980. A larger-scale study using mitochondrial DNA (Rowe et al. 2006) found two lineages of P. leucopus reaching into the Upper Midwest, a western lineage extending from southern Illinois to northern Minnesota and an eastern lineage extending from western Tennessee northward to the Lower Peninsula (LP) of Michigan and eastward to Nova Scotia; that study, however, included very few samples from the northern Great Lakes region, with no samples from Michigan's UP. In this study, we use mtDNA from populations across northern Wisconsin and Michigan to investigate the history of P. leucopus in this area, focusing on the origins of the newly established populations as well as their putative progenitor populations.

Sampling.-Five hundred eighty-four tissue samples were obtained from mice collected in 39 counties in Michigan and Wisconsin, encompassing much of the range of P. leucopus in these states, including newly invaded localities (Fig. 1 ). Each population was named based on the county of origin (see Supplementary Data SD1 for full county names, sample sizes, and geographic coordinates). Multiple trapping sites that were within 25 km of each other and in similar habitat were considered to represent a single population, and the geographic midpoint of these combined sites was determined (http://www. geomidpoint.com) and used when calculating geographic distances among populations. Three geographic sampling "regions" were defined: the LP of Michigan (LP; 140 samples from nine counties), the UP of Michigan (UP; 166 samples from nine counties), and Wisconsin (WI; 278 samples from 21 counties).

Collecting sites were in forested areas above 43° north latitude in both Michigan and Wisconsin, and were chosen based on previous knowledge of the local mouse populations, types of vegetation, and accessibility. Adjacent populations were separated by 50 km on average. The majority of samples (405) were from mice live-trapped in Sherman folding traps (H. B. Sherman Co., Tallahassee, Florida) between 2003 and 2007. A piece of tissue of approximately 2 × 2 mm was clipped from the right ear of each animal and placed in a 1.6-ml centrifuge tube with either SET buffer (Brinster et al. 1985) or 100% ethanol. Tissues were stored in a cooler while in the field and later moved to a −20°C laboratory freezer. All fieldcaptured mice were released at the site of capture. Additional samples (179) were obtained from tissue collections of the Michigan State University Museum and the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (Appendix I), and from frozen carcasses provided by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources. Those tissues were collected between 2000 and 2007. Animals were handled according to the Michigan State University Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee protocol # 08/04-108-00, in compliance with the guidelines of the American Society of Mammalogists for the use of wild mammals in research (Sikes et al. 2016) .

Laboratory procedures.-DNA was extracted from mouse ear tissue using Qiagen DNeasy Tissue Kits (Qiagen, Germantown, Maryland) following the manufacturer's protocol. The complete D-loop and some nucleotides of the adjacent tRNAs were amplified using the universal primers L15926 5′ TACACTGGTCTTGTAAACC 3′ and H00651 5′ AAGGCTAGGACCAAACCT 3′, located on the Pro and Phe tRNAs, respectively (Kocher et al. 1989) . Polymerase chain reactions (PCR) were carried out in a volume of 25 μl, containing 1.75 mM of MgCl, 0.2 mM of each dNTP, 1 μM of each primer, 1 U of Platinum Taq (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California), and 50-100 ng of DNA template, on an Eppendorf Mastercycle thermocycler (Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany). After 2 min of denaturation at 95°C, 35 cycles were run under the following conditions: denaturation at 95°C for 45 s, annealing at 56°C for 60 s, and expansion at 72°C for 75 s. DNA products were checked on a 1.5% agarose gel (Invitrogen) and cleaned using QIAquick Gel Extraction Kits (Qiagen) in preparation for direct automated sequencing. DNA was sequenced at the University of Michigan DNA Sequencing Core, in an Applied Biosystems DNA Sequencer, Model 3730 XL (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California). The same primers used in the PCR reactions were also used for sequencing; however, reverse sequencing was usually incomplete because the reaction terminated at approximately 200 base pairs (bp). This phenomenon was also reported by Rowe et al. (2006) while sequencing the control region of P. leucopus and P. maniculatus. According to these authors, sequencing from the Phe tRNA stopped after 180 bp due to a palindromic sequence (GGGGGGAAGGGGGG) that interferes with the reaction. A subset of samples (n = 14) was sequenced twice for quality control purposes and the exact same sequence was obtained in each case. The lengths of the sequences varied between 1,000 and 1,050 bp, depending on the chromatogram quality. A representative sequence of each haplotype is deposited in GenBank (accession numbers GU810187-GU810356).

Gene genealogy.-Sequences were visually checked and edited using Chromas Pro Version 1.49 (Technelysium Pty Ltd.), aligned using ClustalX (Thompson et al. 1997) , and reduced to haplotypes using Collapse 2.1 (http://darwin.uvigo. es). We investigated the model of nucleotide substitution that best suited our data, according to the corrected Akaike information criterion (AICc), using Mega v.5.1 (Tamura et al. 2011) , with gaps and regions with missing data completely excluded from the analysis. The selected model was HKY + G + I with gamma shape parameter = 0.56, and proportion of invariable sites = 0.63. A gene genealogy, based on haplotypes only, was estimated using the maximum likelihood (ML) criterion, implemented by Mega v.5.1. Support for each node was evaluated with 1,000 bootstrap replicates (Felsenstein 1985) . Peromyscus leucopus sequences from Butler Co., Ohio (OH; n = 2); Johnson Co., Illinois (IL; n = 5); and Livingston Co., Michigan (LI; n = 4) were used to represent potential southern refuge sources (Fig. 1 ). Haplotypes were also compared to a subset of haplotypes from Rowe et al. (2006) using BLAST multiple alignment tools. Three samples of P. m. bairdii from the LP (n = 1), WI (n = 1), and OH (n = 1) and 14 P. m. gracilis from the LP (n = 4), UP (n = 5), and WI (n = 5) were used as outgroups in this analysis.
Gene diversity and population structure.-Genetic diversity was estimated at both the nucleotide (∏) and haplotype (H) levels (Nei 1987) using Arlequin 3.11 (Excoffier et al. 2005) .

Spatial population structure and potential barriers to gene flow were investigated using spatial analysis of molecular variance (SAMOVA) v.1 (Dupanloup et al. 2002) . This program performs a simulated annealing procedure that assigns populations to K groups defined a priori. The composition of these groups takes into account the geographic proximity and genetic homogeneity of populations so that the proportion of total variance due to differences between groups (F ct ) is maximized. Spatial population structure was evaluated for K = 2, 3, and 4 groups, with 100 starting conditions; statistical significance was assessed with 1,000 permutations.

Population genetic structure among groups obtained with SAMOVA was inferred by analysis of molecular variance (AMOVA- Excoffier et al. 1992) , using Arlequin 3.11 (Excoffier et al. 2005) . The significance of each estimation was assessed using 1,000 permutations. Because the power of statistical inferences depends on sample size, only samples with eight individuals or more were included in these analyses, unless otherwise noted.

Migration and divergence time.-Migration rates and the timing of population splits were estimated for the groups obtained from SAMOVA, using the isolation with migration model, as implemented by the IMa program (Hey and Nielsen 2007) . The full version of this model can have up to six parameters, when the descendant populations are assumed to have different population mutation rates (θ1 ≠ θ2) and unequal numbers of migrants (m1 ≠ m2), in addition to the population mutation rate of the ancestral population (θa) and time since divergence (t). Eighteen preliminary simulations were run assuming the HKY mutation model (Hasegawa et al. 1985) . Once priors that produced bell-shaped curves were found for each parameter, 1 × 10 6 cycles for the burn-in time and 10 × 10 6 cycles for the Markov chain were run. To assess consistency of the parameters estimated across runs, and insure that the chains were well mixed, each simulation was repeated three times, using an identical setting each time but a different random seed. If the simulations yielded similar results, the one with the highest effective sample size, which is a measurement of the independent points sampled for each parameter, was chosen for estimation of demographic parameters (see below).

The effective population size of females, N ef , was obtained from the equation, N ef = θ/μg, where μ is the mutation rate per year per locus and g is the number of years per generation; similarly, the migration rate between populations per generation is equal to m = mμ; and the divergence time, in generations, is t = t/μ (Nielsen and Wakeley 2001; Nielsen 2004, 2007) . The mutation rate was calculated based on the genetic divergence observed between P. leucopus and P. maniculatus in mtDNA D-loop sequences, assuming a divergence time inferred from the fossil record of 500,000 BP (Hibbard 1968) . Haplotypes for 43 P. leucopus and 37 P. maniculatus were compared; of the 913 aligned sites (after excluding gaps and missing data), there were 82 substitutions (~13%), which yields a mutation rate, μ, of 1.588*10 −7 mutations/year/site for both species. This estimate is roughly the same as the ones obtained by Rowe et al. (2006) and Taylor and Hoffman (2010) using shorter sequences from the same mitochondrial region. However, any estimation based on this rate should be interpreted with caution because of the uncertainty in determining the actual date when P. leucopus and P. maniculatus diverged. Also, a precise estimate of generation length for this species is not attainable because generations overlap and reproductive rates vary, depending on when during the year females are born, which is in turn influenced by geography. In this study, we assumed two generations/year (Millar 1989; Rowe et al. 2006; Centeno-Cuadros et al. 2009; Taylor and Hoffman 2010) .

Isolation by distance.-To investigate whether the pattern of genetic structure observed in P. leucopus might be explained by limited dispersal and isolation by distance, we examined the correlation between genetic and geographic distances using a Mantel test (Mantel 1967) . Pairwise genetic distances (Φst) obtained from Arlequin 3.11 (Excoffier et al. 2005) were linearized Φst (i.e., Φst /(1 − Φst), and log transformed (Rousset 1997) . Pairwise geographic distances were calculated as the shortest distances over the earth's surface between the geographic midpoints of populations. The significance of the correlation between genetic and geographic distances was evaluated using 1,000 permutations. This analysis was carried out using Matlab R2006a (The MathWorks, Inc.); the analysis was performed for the whole sample and for each group obtained with SAMOVA. To visualize the relationship between genetic and geographic distances, we subsequently mapped each population and connected them with color-coded lines based on their levels of genetic similarity.

Sequencing and gene genealogy.-An alignment was constructed using 934 bp of homologous sequence, including the complete mtDNA D-loop from a total of 595 P. leucopus. These sequences included 170 unique haplotypes, of which 134 were found in 1-3 copies and 17 had more than 10 copies, with the maximum number of copies for a single haplotype being 38. The LP and WI regions shared no haplotypes, the UP and WI shared 16, and the UP and LP shared four. Of the four haplotypes shared by the UP and LP, one was shared by Mackinac (UP) and four LP counties (Alpena, Cheboygan, Presque Isle, and Crawford); Chippewa Co. (UP) had one haplotype in common with Cheboygan Co. and another with Alpena Co. (both in the LP); and two haplotypes found in Ontonagon Co. (UP) were shared with Otsego Co. (LP).

A ML model-based tree using 187 sequences (170 P. leucopus haplotypes plus 17 outgroup sequences from P. maniculatus) revealed two well-supported (99% bootstrap) clades representing the two species ( Fig. 2 ; see Supplementary Data SD2 for fully annotated tree). The P. leucopus clade has three main branches: one includes the haplotypes from the Western UP (WUP) and WI (76% bootstrap), a second includes the haplotypes from the LP and Eastern UP (EUP, 94% bootstrap), and a third groups haplotypes from Illinois and Chippewa Co. (CW-IL, 97% bootstrap). The WUP-WI and LP-EUP clades cluster with the western and eastern clades, respectively, described by Rowe et al. (2006; data not shown) .

While most of the haplotypes from the western UP clustered with those from WI, some Chippewa and Mackinac mice in the eastern UP were genetically more similar to LP mice, with only two haplotypes from Chippewa and one from Mackinac found in the WUP-WI clade. Most other haplotypes were in the expected clade based on geography, but there were a few exceptions: one haplotype from the LP (Benzie Co.) clustered with the WUP-WI haplotypes, and one haplotype from WI (Jackson Co.) and another from the western UP (Ontonagon Co.) were found in the LP-EUP clade. Although a relatively large genetic distance separates the WUP-WI and LP-EUP clades (see below), the internal clades are shallow, with very short branches, due to the small number of nucleotide differences between the sequences.

Gene diversity and population structure.-Haplotype diversity across populations was relatively high, between 0.69 and 0.96. However, nucleotide diversity was rather low, from 0.004 to 0.018 (Supplementary Data SD1), as compared to the range of 0.011 to 0.066 between lineages found by Rowe et al. (2006) . There is a general trend toward lower nucleotide diversity in the expansion populations, with an average ∏ of 0.0062 in northern Wisconsin and 0.0058 in the western to central UP, compared with 0.0070 in central Wisconsin and 0.0093 in the LP. The two eastern UP populations, CW and MA, have the highest nucleotide diversity, most likely due to the mixture of mice from both lineages at those sites.

The best SAMOVA results were obtained with K = 2, which indicates that the molecular variation found in these populations is distributed in two groups, in agreement with the results of the gene genealogy (see Supplementary Data SD3 for full SAMOVA results). Increasing the value of K above 2 creates groups that are composed of only one population each, while the variance due to intergroup differences (Фct) remains roughly the same, thus not adding information. The populations from WUP and WI make up one group, while LP and EUP populations define the second. Differences among all populations (Фst) explain over 70% of the genetic variance observed, while differences between the two groups defined by SAMOVA (Фct) account for over 65% of this variance; differentiation among populations within groups is moderate (Фsc = less than 5% of variance; note that Фst is equal to Фct + Фsc).

Migration and divergence time.-The three simulations that were run after the appropriate priors were identified produced very similar results. For each parameter of the model, the posterior probability distributions were smooth and bellshaped. The results suggest that the population that gave rise to these mice split into WUP-WI and LP-EUP clades in the late Pleistocene, about 34,470 BP (range 28,274 to 45,091 BP; see Table 1 ). The populations then presumably experienced demographic expansion, since their female effective population sizes are larger than the size estimated for the refugial population. These estimates of population sizes and migration rates, which are based on a single genetic locus in expanding populations, should be viewed as very approximate. However, they do show a general pattern of postglacial expansion that correlates well with estimates in Rowe et al. (2006) , and they indicate how this species had the capacity to rapidly expand its range again in modern times. Current migration between the western and eastern lineages is near zero and asymmetrical (m1 > m2).

Isolation by distance.-The Mantel test indicated a high and significant positive correlation between genetic and geographic distances among all populations (r = 0.41, P < 0.001). Because this test can be sensitive to extreme values and does not take into account geographic barriers like the Great Lakes, the test was performed separately for each of the two partitions obtained with SAMOVA. A significant positive correlation between genetic and geographic distances was found for both the WUP-WI (r = 0.33, P < 0.01) and LP-EUP (r = 0.58, P < 0.01), even after adjusting for multiple comparisons using a Bonferroni correction. Two maps were generated from the total data set, one connecting populations with genetic differences of Table 1 .-Demographic parameters in Peromyscus leucopus estimated using the isolation with migration model implemented in IMa. θ1, θ2, and θa are the mutation rates of population 1 (LP-EUP), population 2 (WUP-WI), and the ancestral population, respectively; N1, N2, and Na are the effective population sizes of females (number of individuals) for population 1, population 2, and the ancestral population, respectively; m1 and m2 are the migration rates per generation into population 1 from population 2, and into population 2 from population 1, respectively; and t is the time since the two groups split, in years. Conversion of model parameters to demographic parameters is explained in the text. HiPt is the value with the highest frequency (i.e., the mode), and HPD90Lo and HPD90Hi are the lower and upper bounds of the estimated 90% highest posterior density interval. up to 35%, and another connecting populations with differences of over 35% (Fig. 3) .

This study used polymorphism in mtDNA control region sequences to investigate the phylogeography, genetic structure, and historical demography of populations of P. leucopus in the northern Great Lakes region. These mice sort into two well-differentiated, reciprocally monophyletic groups, one comprising populations from Wisconsin and the westerncentral UP (WUP-WI), and the other populations from the LP and eastern UP (LP-EUP). The two groups display an evident genetic signature of postglacial spatial expansion, as shown by the shallow topology of the haplotype tree, which has a small number of widespread haplotypes and a large number of haplotypes with only 1-3 copies. Also, the gene diversity indices (Supplementary Data SD1) reveal high haplotype diversity and low nucleotide diversity, due to the presence of many derived haplotypes that are differentiated by only a few mutations (Hewitt 2000; Taylor and Keller 2007) . The time estimate for the split between WI and LP mice, 34,470 BP (Table 1) , suggests that these populations began to diverge thousands of years prior to the formation of Lake Michigan (about 13,000 BP- Holman 2001) . At that time, the mice may have occupied a common refugium or multiple different refugia outside of the glaciated region (Rowe et al. 2006 ); subsequently, as they expanded into newly habitable lands, populations may have become isolated during cooling cycles. Later, the formation of Lake Michigan would have reinforced this isolation.

The SAMOVA suggests that Lake Michigan has been an effective barrier to gene flow between WI and Michigan's LP, but that the Straits of Mackinac, which connect Lake Michigan to Lake Huron, are not an effective barrier to gene flow between Michigan's LP and the easternmost UP. Thus, newly founded mouse populations in the UP have two distinct origins, one in Wisconsin and the other in the LP, and represent a new contact zone between two well-established lineages. Genetic differences between mice from the WUP-WI and LP-EUP regions explain more than 65% of the total genetic variation observed in our sample, and the partition supported by this analysis is consistent with the WUP-WI and LP-EUP clades found in the gene genealogy. This partition is also consistent with the Mantel test results, which show a correlation between genetic and geographic distances that is positive and statistically significant for both of the groups identified by SAMOVA (WUP-WI: r = 0.33, P < 0.01; LP-EUP: r = 0.58, P < 0.01). A strong pattern of isolation-by-distance was to be expected given that we used a maternally inherited genetic marker (mtDNA); dispersal in P. leucopus is known to be male-biased (Jacquot and Vessey 1995) , and thus nuclear markers would provide a better estimate of the relationship between genetic and geographic distances for these populations. , with colder colors (i.e., blue-green) indicating high-genetic similarity, and warmer colors (i.e., orange-red) low-genetic similarity. The map on the left connects populations with genetic differences of up to 35%, capturing mostly intraregional comparisons, while the map on the right connects populations with genetic differences of > 35%, capturing interregional comparisons.

The major anomaly revealed by this study is the apparent permeability of the Straits of Mackinac, with mice from the easternmost UP being part of the same clade as those from the LP. This might be explained by ancestral polymorphism, natural dispersal (across ice or by rafting), or human-mediated dispersal. Given that WI and LP mice have no haplotypes in common and are reciprocally monophyletic, ancestral polymorphism seems unlikely. Natural dispersal, although possible, would require that the mice have repeatedly crossed substantial water barriers. Accidental transport by humans seems the best explanation for the movement of mice between the LP and the eastern end of the UP, a movement facilitated by the Mackinac Bridge, which has connected these two landmasses for the past 62 years. Human transport is also the most likely explanation for a few mice that cluster with geographically distant populations, such as a genetically LP-EUP mouse that was collected in central Wisconsin and several mice from the Illinois clade collected in Chippewa Co. in the easternmost UP (Supplementary Data SD2).

Two studies that looked at mitochondrial and microsatellite markers in Great Lakes P. m. gracilis Hoffman 2010, 2012) provide an interesting comparison to these results. Similar to P. leucopus, the P. m. gracilis mtDNA haplotypes form a shallow tree with eastern and western mitochondrial clades, and the easternmost UP mice cluster with the LP mice. However, the eastern UP P. m. gracilis are from long-established populations (Myers et al. 2009 ) that apparently colonized the area sometime in the last 11,000 years via natural dispersal (Taylor and Hoffman 2010) . Human transport of P. m. gracilis between the LP and the eastern UP is likely ongoing, but any recently transported LP mice cannot be distinguished from the postglacial colonists by using mtDNA, since those two groups already share haplotypes. Microsatellite markers do distinguish UP from LP P. m. gracilis populations, but there is little genetic structure within each peninsula, suggesting that substantial gene flow between eastern and western UP mice during the last 11,000 years has homogenized their nuclear markers (Taylor and Hoffman 2012) .

In contrast, P. leucopus was first detected in the eastern UP in 2002 (Myers et al. 2009 ) and these very new populations include haplotypes from several different clusters within the LP-EUP mtDNA clade (Supplementary Data SD2), indicating that there have been repeated recent transfers of mice from the LP to the eastern UP, most likely due to accidental human transport. Peromyscus leucopus microsatellite markers show high genetic diversity within and low differentiation among populations from the LP and the eastern and central UP, with no apparent founder effects in newly established populations and no sorting by mtDNA lineages (Taylor and Hoffman 2014; Baumgartner and Hoffman 2019) . This is consistent with a scenario of rapid expansion of P. leucopus into the UP from two sources, human-transferred mice in the east and natural migrants plus some transferred mice in the west, followed by substantial numbers of migrants moving among the new populations. Additional analyses of independent nuclear loci in the future could provide a more detailed picture of the recent expansion of each lineage and of their hybridization in the UP.

Implications.-The recent increase in geographic range and population density of P. leucopus in the northern Great Lakes region is impacting the more boreal P. m. gracilis, which was until recently the only species of Peromyscus found in most of the UP (Myers et al. 2009) . The ecological consequences of this are unknown but may be significant, as mice from the genus Peromyscus numerically dominate most small mammal communities in this region. A graver concern, however, is the surprising extent to which P. leucopus is apparently being moved about the region by humans. If P. leucopus is being transported long distances from Lyme disease hotspots such as the one in Wisconsin, it could facilitate the spread of this disease at a more rapid rate and across wider areas than is currently anticipated.

Supplementary data are available at Journal of Mammalogy online.Supplementary Data SD1.-Sampling localities with geographic coordinates, sample size, number of haplotypes observed, haplotype diversity, number of segregating sites over complete sequence, and nucleotide diversity.Supplementary Data SD2.-Fully annotated ML tree showing the haplotype genealogy of Peromyscus leucopus in the northern Great Lakes populations sampled in this study. Haplotypes that are not in the expected clade given collection locality and the results of the spatial analysis of molecular variance (SAMOVA) are marked with double asterisks ('**') and highlighted in a different color. Only bootstrap support values above 50% are shown.Supplementary Data SD3.-Spatial population structure of Peromyscus leucopus in the northern Great Lakes Region, as

FIGREF0.text: -Geographic location of Peromyscus leucopus populations analyzed in this study. Each population was named for county of origin (see Supplementary Data SD1 for full county names, sample sizes, and geographic coordinates). Black circles indicate populations within the former northern limit of the species in this region. Gray circles indicate populations in newly invaded localities.

FIGREF1.text: -ML tree showing the haplotype genealogy of Peromyscus leucopus in the northern Great Lakes populations sampled in this study. The names of the clades are based on haplotype composition, i.e., WUP-WI, Michigan's western Upper Peninsula and Wisconsin; LP-EUP, Michigan's Lower Peninsula and eastern Upper Peninsula; and CW-IL, Chippewa County Michigan and Illinois. Peromyscus maniculatus (Pm) is the outgroup (see Supplementary Data SD2 for a fully annotated version of this tree).

FIGREF2.text: -Interconnectivity among Peromyscus leucopus populations based on pairwise genetic distances. The color of the line indicates genetic distance between population pairs, based on pairwise Φst/1 − Φst values
